Pronghorn (Antilocapra americana)

Though their genus name, Antilocapra, means âantelope goatâ, pronghorns are neither. The difference is in the antlers. Those of deer are shed every year; those of antelope and goats never are. Pronghorns shed theirs annually, but only the outer layer, which is made up of keratin, like your hair.

Pronghorns are the fastest land mammal of the Americas, sprinting at speeds of up to 55 mph (88 km/h). They are built for running, with a light bone structure and even hollow hair to make them lighter; it is hypothesized that their speed evolved to escape the now-extinct American cheetah, since no living North American predator can keep up with them. Their sprint is one of 13 distinct gaits they exhibit.

Pronghorns come together in the winter, forming mixed-sex herds; in the summer the sexes split up, with adult females and their young forming small herds, young bachelor males grouping together, and adult males living independently.
